Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Investigation of Electron Migration and Trapping in Doped Luminescent Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: This research project involves the study of electron-hole (e-h) pair transport and trapping processes in solid-state luminescent materials under vacuum ultraviolet excitation. These materials are comprised of an oxide host and a rare-earth dopant. Under vacuum ultraviolet excitation, an e-h pair is created in the host that must migrate and be trapped by the dopant for luminescence to occur. The research project addresses two fundamental questions: (1) How is the efficiency of e-h transfer affected by the position of dopant states relative to host band states? (2) How much does the choice of dopant influence the degree of surface loss observed in particles with sizes of from 50 to 500 nanometers? This is accomplished through systematic spectroscopic investigations of materials of controlled particle size, and the evaluation of these data in the context of current models. The analysis and modeling of these experimental data allow for the assessment of the mobility of e-h pairs in a given host, as well as the degree to which absorbed energy is lost to bulk defects versus surface traps. Such a differentiation is especially important to the development of efficient nanoscale optical materials that have an intrinsically high surface area. The project also applies these methods to larger bandgap phosphate hosts.

Non-technical Description: The objective of this research is to understand the fundamental structure/property relationships that govern the efficiency of solid-state luminescent materials, especially materials with sub-micrometer particle sizes, under vacuum ultraviolet excitation. Such materials often exhibit properties different from their bulk counterparts, and can improve the performance of certain technologies such as in high-definition displays. The PI has established a rigorous research program in solid-state chemistry at Central Washington University, with undergraduate students comprising the bulk of the investigative team. Students are gaining a deeper and broader scientific training, which serves as excellent preparation for graduate school or future professional endeavors. Undergraduate students trained in the PI's lab often published papers in peer-reviewed journals and routinely go on to pursue graduate degrees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research involved the study of electron-hole pair migration and trapping in doped luminescent materials.  We seek to understand the important structure / property relationships that dictate efficient migration and trapping, with the ultimate goal of developing predictive models.  Understanding these processes is important to a variety of fields in materials science, including transparent conductors, solar cells, and luminescent materials.

One important outcome was the study of YBO3 doped with seven different trivalent rare earth ions.  Under vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) excitation, an electron hole pair is created in the YBO3 host that migrates until it is trapped by the activator (the doped ion) or by lattice defects (killers).  Using excitation and reflectance spectroscopy we were able to calculate the host-to-activator transfer efficiency.  The tranfer efficiency is the fraction of e-h pairs captured by the dopant.  Tranfer efficiencies were calcluated across a range of dopant concentrations, and the data were fit using accepted kinetic models.  The fits yield an alpha/beta ratio, which is an indication of the relative efficiency of e-h migration and trapping.  The results were interpreted in terms of the energy level scheme for this system, which describes the location of dopant energy levels relative to host valence and conduction bands (see Figure 1).  We found that dopants can be classified as electron traps or hole traps, and that the alpha / beta ratio scales with trap depth (Figure 2).  These data were published in the Journal of Luminescence, and represent the first systematic characterization of e-h migration and trapping under VUV excitation.  The results indicate that it may be possible to predict the trapping efficiency of a given host / dopant combination from the energy level scheme.

A second significant outcome was the characterization of rare earth doped YPO4 prepared via different synthetic routes.  Solid state reaction produces crystallites of about 330 nm, while a co-precipitation method yields crystallites of about 20 nm.  The samples prepared by solid state reaction exhibit an unusually high efficiency when excited right at the YPO4 band edge (150 nm).  This efficiency is lost in the samples prepared via co-precipitation (see Figure 3).  Transfer efficiency measurments were carried out at several dopant concentrations for both preparations.  By fitting these data (Figure 4), we were able to estimate that 60 - 70% of absorbed energy is lost to surface or interface states in the co-precipitated samples.  Understanding the reasons for the unusual excitation efficiency, as well as it's loss at small particle sizes, will aid in the development of more efficient nano materials.

Ongoing work includes the study of particle size effects in rare earth doped YBO3, as well as the study of the role of defects in reducing transfer efficiency in doped YBO3 and YPO4.  Defects are generated by introducing a charge mismatch in the lattice through the addition of Ca2+.

The PI has a distinguished record of working with undergraduate students who go on to pursue graduate degrees.  The group this year included two women, a US militar veteran, and a member of the Suqamish tribe of Yakama, WA.  The PI is particularly proud of the fact that two of the community colleges in the state have female faculty in chemistry that started their academic careers in the PI's research group.

The PI also regularly teaches in the Science Talent Expansion Program at Central Washington University.  This program is designed to recruit and retain students in STEM fields by connecting them with like minded students, as well as with research faculty.  The program specifically targets groups tradionally under represented in the sciences.


Last Modified: 08/04/2017
Modified by: Anthony L Diaz

  • Alpha/beta ratios of rare earths doped in YBO3 determined from spectroscopic measurements of host-to-activator transfer efficiency, plotted versus trap depth. Dopants have been separated into hole traps and electron traps.
    J. Lumin. 161, 403 (2015)

  • Excitation spectra of YPO4:Eu prepared via co-precipitation (dashed line) and prepared by traditional solid-state methods (solid line). An unusually intense peak is present for excitation at the band edge (150 nm) that decreases dramatically in samples prepared by co-precipitation.
    submitted to ECS Solid State Sci. Tech.
    Copyrighted
    Anthony L Diaz
    Excitation spectrum of YPO4:Eu
  • Transfer efficiency versus Eu3+ concentration for YPO4:Eu3+ prepared by co-precipitation (open diamonds) and solid state grinding and firing (circles). Samples prepared via co-precipitation exhibit markedly lower transfer efficiency due to surface states or an amorphous phase
    submitted to ECS Solid State Sci. Tech.

    Transfer Efficiency vs [Eu]
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This research involved the study of electron-hole pair migration and trapping in doped luminescent materials. We seek to understand the important structure / property relationships that dictate efficient migration and trapping, with the ultimate goal of developing predictive models. Understanding these processes is important to a variety of fields in materials science, including transparent conductors, solar cells, and luminescent materials. One important outcome was the study of YBO3 doped with seven different trivalent rare earth ions. Under vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) excitation, an electron hole pair is created in the YBO3 host that migrates until it is trapped by the activator (the doped ion) or by lattice defects (killers). Using excitation and reflectance spectroscopy we were able to calculate the host-to-activator transfer efficiency. The tranfer efficiency is the fraction of e-h pairs captured by the dopant. Tranfer efficiencies were calcluated across a range of dopant concentrations, and the data were fit using accepted kinetic models. The fits yield an alpha/beta ratio, which is an indication of the relative efficiency of e-h migration and trapping. The results were interpreted in terms of the energy level scheme for this system, which describes the location of dopant energy levels relative to host valence and conduction bands (see Figure 1). We found that dopants can be classified as electron traps or hole traps, and that the alpha / beta ratio scales with trap depth (Figure 2). These data were published in the Journal of Luminescence, and represent the first systematic characterization of e-h migration and trapping under VUV excitation. The results indicate that it may be possible to predict the trapping efficiency of a given host / dopant combination from the energy level scheme. A second significant outcome was the characterization of rare earth doped YPO4 prepared via different synthetic routes. Solid state reaction produces crystallites of about 330 nm, while a co-precipitation method yields crystallites of about 20 nm. The samples prepared by solid state reaction exhibit an unusually high efficiency when excited right at the YPO4 band edge (150 nm). This efficiency is lost in the samples prepared via co-precipitation (see Figure 3). Transfer efficiency measurments were carried out at several dopant concentrations for both preparations. By fitting these data (Figure 4), we were able to estimate that 60 - 70% of absorbed energy is lost to surface or interface states in the co-precipitated samples. Understanding the reasons for the unusual excitation efficiency, as well as it's loss at small particle sizes, will aid in the development of more efficient nano materials. Ongoing work includes the study of particle size effects in rare earth doped YBO3, as well as the study of the role of defects in reducing transfer efficiency in doped YBO3 and YPO4. Defects are generated by introducing a charge mismatch in the lattice through the addition of Ca2+. The PI has a distinguished record of working with undergraduate students who go on to pursue graduate degrees. The group this year included two women, a US militar veteran, and a member of the Suqamish tribe of Yakama, WA. The PI is particularly proud of the fact that two of the community colleges in the state have female faculty in chemistry that started their academic careers in the PI's research group. The PI also regularly teaches in the Science Talent Expansion Program at Central Washington University. This program is designed to recruit and retain students in STEM fields by connecting them with like minded students, as well as with research faculty.
